org.macroing.gdt.openrc.geometry

Class Vector

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.macroing.gdt.openrc.geometry.Vector

  • public final class Vector
extends java.lang.Object
    A class that consists exclusively of static methods that performs various operations on vectors.
    Since:
    1.0.0
    Author:
    Jörgen Lundgren

    • Method Detail

      • dotProduct

        public static float dotProduct(float[] vector0,
                               int offset0,
                               float[] vector1,
                               int offset1)
        Returns the dot product between two vectors.

        The first vector corresponds to X, Y and Z, located at vector0[offset0], vector0[offset0 + 1] and vector0[offset0 + 2], respectively.

        The second vector corresponds to X, Y and Z, located at vector1[offset1], vector1[offset1 + 1] and vector1[offset1 + 2], respectively.

        If either vector0 or vector1 are null, a NullPointerException will be thrown.

        If offset0 is less than 0 or offset0 + 2 is greater than or equal to vector0.length, or offset1 is less than 0 or offset1 + 2 is greater than or equal to vector1.length, an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException will be thrown.

        Parameters:
        vector0 - a float array with one or more vectors in
        offset0 - the start offset in vector0
        vector1 - a float array with one or more vectors in
        offset1 - the start offset in vector1
        Returns:
        the dot product between two vectors
        Throws:
        java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - thrown if, and only if, offset0 is less than 0 or offset0 + 2 is greater than or equal to vector0.length, or offset1 is less than 0 or offset1 + 2 is greater than or equal to vector1.length
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if, and only if, either vector0 or vector1 are null

      • length

        public static float length(float[] vector,
                           int offset)
        Returns the length of a vector.

        The vector corresponds to X, Y and Z, located at vector[offset], vector[offset + 1] and vector[offset + 2], respectively.

        If vector is null, a NullPointerException will be thrown.

        If offset is less than 0 or offset + 2 is greater than or equal to vector.length, an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException will be thrown.

        Parameters:
        vector - a float array with one or more vectors in
        offset - the start offset in vector
        Returns:
        the length of a vector
        Throws:
        java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - thrown if, and only if, offset is less than 0 or offset + 2 is greater than or equal to vector.length
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if, and only if, vector is null

      • lengthSquared

        public static float lengthSquared(float[] vector,
                                  int offset)
        Returns the squared length of a vector.

        The vector corresponds to X, Y and Z, located at vector[offset], vector[offset + 1] and vector[offset + 2], respectively.

        If vector is null, a NullPointerException will be thrown.

        If offset is less than 0 or offset + 2 is greater than or equal to vector.length, an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException will be thrown.

        Parameters:
        vector - a float array with one or more vectors in
        offset - the start offset in vector
        Returns:
        the squared length of a vector
        Throws:
        java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - thrown if, and only if, offset is less than 0 or offset + 2 is greater than or equal to vector.length
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if, and only if, vector is null

      • surfaceNormal

        public static float[] surfaceNormal(float aX,
                                    float aY,
                                    float aZ,
                                    float bX,
                                    float bY,
                                    float bZ,
                                    float cX,
                                    float cY,
                                    float cZ)
        Returns a float array with the vector corresponding to the surface normal of the provided X-, Y- and Z-components.

        The returned float array will have a length of 3, and the vectors X-, Y- and Z-components will be located at indices 0, 1 and 2, respectively.

        Parameters:
        aX - the X-component of the A vector
        aY - the Y-component of the A vector
        aZ - the Z-component of the A vector
        bX - the X-component of the B vector
        bY - the Y-component of the B vector
        bZ - the Z-component of the B vector
        cX - the X-component of the C vector
        cY - the Y-component of the C vector
        cZ - the Z-component of the C vector
        Returns:
        a float array with the vector corresponding to the surface normal of the provided X-, Y- and Z-components

      • crossProduct

        public static void crossProduct(float[] vector0,
                                int offset0,
                                float[] vector1,
                                int offset1,
                                float[] vector2,
                                int offset2)
        Calculates the cross product of two vectors.

        The first vector corresponds to X, Y and Z, located at vector0[offset0], vector0[offset0 + 1] and vector0[offset0 + 2], respectively.

        The second vector corresponds to X, Y and Z, located at vector1[offset1], vector1[offset1 + 1] and vector1[offset1 + 2], respectively.

        The third vector corresponds to X, Y and Z, located at vector2[offset2], vector2[offset2 + 1] and vector2[offset2 + 2], respectively.

        The first and second vectors are part of the cross product calculation. The third vector is where the result will be found after the calculation finishes.

        If either vector0, vector1 or vector2 are null, a NullPointerException will be thrown.

        If offset0 is less than 0 or offset0 + 2 is greater than or equal to vector0.length, or offset1 is less than 0 or offset1 + 2 is greater than or equal to vector1.length, or offset2 is less than 0 or offset2 + 2 is greater than or equal to vector2.length, an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException will be thrown.

        Parameters:
        vector0 - a float array with one or more vectors in
        offset0 - the start offset in vector0
        vector1 - a float array with one or more vectors in
        offset1 - the start offset in vector1
        vector2 - a float array with one or more vectors in
        offset2 - the start offset in vector2
        Throws:
        java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - thrown if, and only if, offset0 is less than 0 or offset0 + 2 is greater than or equal to vector0.length, or offset1 is less than 0 or offset1 + 2 is greater than or equal to vector1.length, or offset2 is less than 0 or offset2 + 2 is greater than or equal to vector2.length
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if, and only if, either vector0, vector1 or vector2 are null

      • normalize

        public static void normalize(float[] vector,
                             int offset)
        Performs vector normalization.

        The vector corresponds to X, Y and Z, located at vector[offset], vector[offset + 1] and vector[offset + 2], respectively.

        The original vector will be overwritten by the normalized representation of itself.

        If vector is null, a NullPointerException will be thrown.

        If offset is less than 0 or offset + 2 is greater than or equal to vector.length, an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException will be thrown.

        Parameters:
        vector - a float array with one or more vectors in
        offset - the start offset in vector
        Throws:
        java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - thrown if, and only if, offset is less than 0 or offset + 2 is greater than or equal to vector.length
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if, and only if, vector is null

      • subtract

        public static void subtract(float[] vector0,
                            int offset0,
                            float[] vector1,
                            int offset1,
                            float[] vector2,
                            int offset2)
        Subtracts one vector from another one.

        The first vector corresponds to X, Y and Z, located at vector0[offset0], vector0[offset0 + 1] and vector0[offset0 + 2], respectively.

        The second vector corresponds to X, Y and Z, located at vector1[offset1], vector1[offset1 + 1] and vector1[offset1 + 2], respectively.

        The third vector corresponds to X, Y and Z, located at vector2[offset2], vector2[offset2 + 1] and vector2[offset2 + 2], respectively.

        The first and second vectors are part of the subtraction calculation. The third vector is where the result will be found after the calculation finishes.

        Think of the subtraction calculation as vector0 - vector1.

        If either vector0, vector1 or vector2 are null, a NullPointerException will be thrown.

        If offset0 is less than 0 or offset0 + 2 is greater than or equal to vector0.length, or offset1 is less than 0 or offset1 + 2 is greater than or equal to vector1.length, or offset2 is less than 0 or offset2 + 2 is greater than or equal to vector2.length, an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException will be thrown.

        Parameters:
        vector0 - a float array with one or more vectors in
        offset0 - the start offset in vector0
        vector1 - a float array with one or more vectors in
        offset1 - the start offset in vector1
        vector2 - a float array with one or more vectors in
        offset2 - the start offset in vector2
        Throws:
        java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - thrown if, and only if, offset0 is less than 0 or offset0 + 2 is greater than or equal to vector0.length, or offset1 is less than 0 or offset1 + 2 is greater than or equal to vector1.length, or offset2 is less than 0 or offset2 + 2 is greater than or equal to vector2.length
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if, and only if, either vector0, vector1 or vector2 are null
